oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Profitability of preconditioning: lessons learned from an 11-year case study of an Indiana beef herd
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hilton, W. Mark
Olynk, Nicole J.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: preconditioning
feedlot
viral respiratory diseases
vaccination
beef herd
profit
economic
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Preconditioning (PC) generally refers to methods used to adequately prepare a calf for a successful feedlot experience. The details of various preconditioning programs have been annotated elsewhere. In all programs, calves are vaccinated for viral respiratory diseases and seven to eight clostridial organisms; dewormed; treated for lice and grubs; bulls are castrated; and horned calves are dehorned. In most programs calves are weaned for â‰¥ 30 days, and calves are trained to eat from a bank and drink from a fountain or tank.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2012; 190
